Caesar, he adds, only smiled when he saw it there, and refused to have it taken down. Servius commenting on the passage in Vergil (Aen. xi. 743), where Tarchon wrenches Venulus fully armed from his horse, says that the incident is taken from history, for that the thing happened to Caesar when he was fighting in Gaul. But one of the enemy recognising him as he was being carried away by his antagonist, shouted out, ‘ Caesar, Caesar,' which in Gallie means ‘ Let him go,’ and he was let go. This story is given to us on the authority of Caesar himself in his ‘ Diary ’ (Ephemm's), where he is dwelling on his own good fortune! Even if there is any truth in the narrative, there is no particular reason for assigning it to this occasion, beyond the fact that Caesar was undoubtedly now at the lowest ebb os his fortunes.
